title: 美元商店的经济学

note:
Analyst House Gartner警告了用户不要将数据管理产品与三大云极高的超声波混合起来。
 随着AWS，Microsoft Azure和Google Cloud平台领导包装，云基础设施提供商在Q1中看到支出达到418亿美元，根据Canaalys一年同期的35％。虽然组织在基础设施方面采用了一些对冲，但在Gartner的VP分析师VP分析师Sanjeev Mohan表示，虽然涉及数据管理和分析，但最好坚持一名球员。
 虽然AWS，Azure和GCP都有优势和数据工具集中的弱点，但莫汉告诉Gartner数据＆amp，几乎没有尝试选择每个供应商的最佳技术;本周分析峰会。
   ＆＃34;仔细踩踏。如果你＆＃39; re new和你说，我想成为多云，然后再想一想。这是一个全职工作，保持单一的云，并了解所有细微差别，[你没有时间]去开始投资多个云。＆＃34;
      虽然Mohan使用他的会议讨论他们的数据和分析堆栈中每个最大的云提供商提供的技术，其中一个人归功于您的样子。
 ＆＃34;任何这些云提供商都将从业务角度工作，问题更加非功能性：您有什么技能？如果您是Microsoft Shop，则使用Azure，因为您熟悉Microsoft工具。如果您有一个非常复杂的IT商店，并且您想要一系列巨大的产品，您很乐意做大量的工程，那么AWS为您提供更多选择。如果您是开源作为部门，那么谷歌云，＆＃34;莫汉说。
   如果您＆＃39;重新选择为数据平台挑选云提供商，Mohan提供了长期列表的标准列表，包括一致性，开源VS专有，易于部署，数据摄取，数据访问，性能，可扩展性等。 
只是因为你＆＃39;在他们的云中没有意味着你必须使用多亿美元提供者和＃39; s数据工具。经过一点栅栏坐着，手工缠绕而不是＆＃34;对数百种产品，我们每周覆盖非本机工具，＆＃34; Mohan承认，Informatica拥有大量的数据工程产品。 Apache Kafka，Snowflake和Newbie数据摄取Unicorn Fivetran也得到了尊贵的提及。
   但是，不要忘记老朋友。尽管Hadoop的平流层升起和笨拙的堕落，但主要云提供商的堆栈提供了一些隐藏大象的痕迹。例如，微软已经埋藏了HDInsight的托管服务。曾经依赖HortonWorks，它现在使用Microsoft Distro。 AWS有弹性MapReduce，一个用于批量和在线处理的管理Hadoop和Spark Service。同样，谷歌依赖于Hadoop，它激发的分布式文件系统，在其DataProc工具中创建持久对象以及数据融合，数据转换产品。 ®
     英国艺术家寻求＆＃39; luvvie levy＆＃39;在新的小工具上弥补消费者在线访问的所有媒体
     世界领先的灯光＆＃34;艺术＆＃34;已呼吁在手机，笔记本电脑和电脑上征税，以帮助融资创意产业，他们声称因缺乏收入和资金而被蹂躏。

  它说，一部分推理的一部分是倡议，是它将有助于纠正通过直接支付的人们访问音乐，电影和其他创意物料的人们造成的平衡。

  ＆＃39;所有软件都必须安全且安全地部署在我们提供的指南内，＆＃39;外包说
     法国外包员ATOS在非部门政府机构的工人请求的流行和开源软件中，From French Outsourcer Atos每一直在为NHS英格兰充电。
  根据登记册看到的文件，NHS英国的数据工作人员必须通过他们的线路管理要求FOSS包。这些是由外包员履行的，作为其2019年6月签署的卫生和社会护理部的136万英镑协议的一部分。

  这似乎是由于指数，最终是在开曼群岛，希望在英国在英国发布交易所，以来，自今年年初以来，英国的加密货币公司必须注册全国＆＃39;金融行为权，符合其反洗钱和反恐资助需求。

  我们希望这家酒店有一个漂亮的水疗中心，因为Windows确定看起来需要一些R＆amp; r 
Bork！Bork！Bork！微软Windows的能力对于它的能力来说是偏离任何地方，但这是我们认为，它第一次在酒店的一侧羞辱。
  ＆＃34; 4星级酒店正在使用2星级操作系统，似乎，＆＃34;我们的读者说，周末发现了博格，在英国萨默塞特·布里奇沃特的墙壁上涂抹了。

  佛罗里达州的淡水甲壳类动物Boffins的一项研究表明，将抗抑郁药喂养到小龙虾可以使它们更加开除和冒险 - 或多或少是如何定义抗抑郁药应该如何工作的定义。在人类，至少。
  该实验提出了研究抗抑郁药的接触程度可能影响野外小龙虾行为，因为人类药物污染物是淡水环境中的增加因素。
  为此，它们创造了“20个椭圆形循环的人工流”，每个流是它们充满60升无化学地下水。在每个人造溪流中，他们在一端为小龙虾造成了避难所，开始进入，这导致了两个单独的路径：用鱼明胶调味以发出食物来源;另一个小龙虾填充的另一个潜在挑起了激进的反应。
  继续阅读 
M1中的m是呻吟：如何将新的MacBook Pro转换为桌面主控？
     M1 MacBook Pro就像那个辉煌的同事，他们坚持在办公室小厨房里的微波。善于工作，当然，也是深深的烦人。
  一方面，这台机器是一个名副其实的野兽。它快速，安静，并拥有此评论家使用的任何机器的最佳电池寿命。然而，它遭受了两个不同的缺陷。首先，它依赖于两个USB-C（在这种情况下，Thunderbolt 4）端口进行外部可扩展性。其次，无论出于何种原因，它本地只支持一个外部显示器。
  幸运的是，这些是非常简单的，因为你提供了一些深口袋。几周前，anker向我们发送了它的Powerexpand 5-In-1霹雳4码头审查。价格为200英镑，＆＃39;不便宜。
  继续阅读
  赞助云的进度，组织IT基础设施比组织披萨交付更难。
  根据MarketsandMarkets，到2021年底，云数据中心将处理超过总工作量的94％。这很容易解释为什么企业迁移到云：像如何简单的公司从提供者租用能力和解决方案。但是，所有与虚拟机更相关的所有内容。 
专用服务器周围的情况并不像简单。然而，它们仍然对某些任务仍然不可或缺，并允许客户的业务充分利用其基础架构。我们对裸裸金属服务器的审查将显示它们的优势，当它们是必不可少的，如何将它们无缝地集成到公司IT基础架构中。
  继续阅读
  哈勃望远镜在另一个紧张的地方：在天体物理学家之间争吵在一个＆＃39;暗物质缺乏＆＃39;星系
  一支球队称，DF2是72米的人，另一个不同意 - 我们与双方说话
     毫无介意辐射的记忆错误。几十年古老的哈勃太空望远镜的另一部分变化已经发现了果酱。这次其相机单元再次在科学家之间的冲突中，无论是Galaxy NGC 1052-DF2是否包含任何暗物质。
  当DF2在2018年在自然纸上写出时，研究立即抬起眉毛。本文得出结论，星系缺乏暗物质。怎么可能？
  神秘的物质被认为是在所有星系中存在，持有闪闪发光的星星，粉尘和天然气的漩涡，更多，给星系结构和形状。暗物质是银河形成理论的重要组成部分，并在没有这种隐藏的东西的情况下找到星系，或者它的数量非常低，打破所有规则。 DF2被告警，作为一个重要的奇怪。 
继续阅读  注册 - 对科技界的独立新闻和意见。 部分情况出版
note_en:
Analyst house Gartner has warned users not to mix and match data management products from the three largest cloud hyperscalers.
 With AWS, Microsoft Azure, and Google Cloud Platform leading the pack, cloud infrastructure providers saw spending hit $41.8bn in Q1, 35 per cent up on a year earlier  according to Canalys. While organisations employ some hedging in terms of infrastructure, when it comes to data management and analytics, it is best to stick with one player, said Sanjeev Mohan, VP analyst at Gartner.
 Although AWS, Azure, and GCP all have strengths and weaknesses in the data toolset, there was little to gain from trying to pick the best technologies from each vendor, Mohan told the Gartner Data & Analytics Summit this week.
   "Tread carefully. If you're new and you say, I want to be multi-cloud, then think again. It is a full-time job keeping up with a single cloud, and understand[ing] all the nuances, [you don't have time] to go and start investing in multiple clouds."
      While Mohan used his session to discuss the technologies offered by each of the biggest cloud providers in their data and analytics stack, which one to go with comes down to what kind of user you are.
 "Any of these cloud providers will work for you from a business point of view, the question is more non-functional: what skills do you have? If you are a Microsoft shop, then go with Azure, because you're familiar with Microsoft tools. If you have a very sophisticated IT shop and you want a vast breadth of products and you are happy to do a lot of engineering then AWS provides you with more choices. If you are open source as a department, then Google Cloud," Mohan said.
   If you're into picking your cloud provider for a data platform, Mohan offered a long list of criteria, including consistency, open source vs proprietary, ease of deployment, data ingest, data access, performance, scalability, and so on.
 Just because you're in their cloud doesn't mean you have to go with the multibillion-dollar provider's data tools either. After a bit of fence sitting and hand wringing about not being "unfair to hundreds of products that we cover on weekly basis on non-native tools," Mohan conceded that Informatica has a vast array of data engineering products. Apache Kafka, Snowflake, and newbie data ingestion unicorn Fivetran got honourable mentions too.
   But let's not forget old friends. Despite the stratospheric rise and ungainly fall of Hadoop, the stacks of the main cloud providers offer traces of a few hidden elephants. Microsoft, for example, has Hadoop buried in managed service HDInsight. Once relying on Hortonworks, it now uses a Microsoft distro. AWS has Elastic MapReduce, a managed Hadoop and Spark service for batch and online processing. Similarly, Google relies on Hadoop, the distributed file system it inspired, in its Dataproc tool for creating persistent objects, as well as in Data Fusion, a data transformation product. ®
     UK artists seek 'luvvie levy' on new gadgets to make up for all the media that consumers access online
     Leading lights in the world of "the arts" have called for a techy tax on mobiles, laptops, and PCs to help finance creative industries they claim have been ravaged by lack of revenue and funding.
  DACS – the visual artists' rights management nonprofit – reckons a levy of 1-2 per cent on the sale of new tech gadgets could help raise £250m-£300m a year.
  Part of the reasoning behind the initiative, it said, is that it would help redress the balance caused by people accessing music, films, and other creative material online without paying for it directly.
  Continue reading
  Panasonic's Toughbook G2 tablet will feature 10-finger touch even with gloves on and full Windows 11 compatibility.
  Continue reading
  Bezos v Branson: Battle of the wannabe Space Barons as Virgin Galactic cleared by FAA to start flying customers
     A pair of rich white men look set to duke it out at the edge of space after Virgin Galactic was given the green light by the Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) to fly customers to space.
  Continue reading
  Fujitsu wins £9m contract hike for Oracle HR system running nearly 3 years late at Northern Ireland Education Authority
     Fujitsu has been awarded a £9.2m contract extension by the Northern Ireland Education Authority for changes to the implementation of an Oracle HR and payroll system that is already nearly three years late.
  The project – first known as the EA Integrated Financial Management Information System, now dubbed EA One Project – began in 2015 with a £20m contract award to the Japanese supplier. But, according to  a tender award notice published last week, the authority said the new award was necessary to "facilitate functionality changes to effectively meet schools' requirements, data migration issues due to the complexity of the variations in employee terms and conditions, and project delays due to COVID-19 lockdowns."
  The notice continued: "This modification will enable the continuation of the existing single contractor managed service arrangement which includes the supply of a broad range of computer and related services, information technology consultancy services and the supply of computer hardware, software and associated products.
  Continue reading
  When free and open source actually means £6k-£8k per package: Atos's £136m contract with NHS England
  'All software must be safely and securely deployed within guidelines provided to us,' says outsourcer
     French outsourcer Atos has been charging NHS England between £6,000 and £8,000 for packing up popular free and open-source software requested by workers in the non-departmental government body.
  According to documents seen by  The Register, data workers in NHS England have to request FOSS packages via their line management. These are fulfilled by outsourcer Atos, as part of  its £136m agreement with the Department of Health and Social Care signed in June 2019.
  Analysts within NHS England who work on strategic planning of one of the world's largest public health systems, as well as assisting with the COVID-19 response, have requested common, freely available open-source packages such as R, the statistical language, and Python, the general-purpose language.
  Continue reading
  The UK's financial watchdog has fired a warning shot across the bow of Binance, and ordered it to place a notice on binance.com scaring off Brit crypto fans.
  This seems to have come about because Binance, which is ultimately based in the Cayman Islands, wanted to launch an exchange in the UK using its London-based affiliate Binance Markets Ltd. Since the start of the year, cryptocurrency firms in Britain have had to register with the nation's Financial Conduct Authority and meet its anti-money-laundering and anti-terrorism-funding requirements.
  Binance hasn't done this yet, or as the FCA itself put it, Binance has demonstrated an "imposition" to the regulator's rules.
  Continue reading
  We hope this hotel has a nice spa because Windows sure looks like it needs some R&R
     Bork!Bork!Bork! Microsoft Windows is notable for its ability to fall over pretty much anywhere, but this is, we think, the first time it has disgraced itself over the side of a hotel.
  "The 4 star hotel is using a 2 star OS for its signage, it seems," said our reader, who spotted the borkage over the weekend, smeared up against the wall of the Mercure Bridgwater in Somerset, England.
  Continue reading
  A study by freshwater crustacean boffins in Florida has revealed that feeding antidepressants to crayfish can make them more outgoing and adventurous — which is more or less a definition of how antidepressants are supposed to work. On humans, at least.
  The experiment set out to investigate how exposure to antidepressants might affect crayfish behaviour in the wild, since human pharmaceutical pollutants are an increasing factor in freshwater environments.
  To do this, they created “20 oval-shaped recirculating artificial streams,” each of which they filled with 60 litres of chemical-free groundwater. In each artificial stream, they built a shelter at one end for the crayfish to start in, which led to two separate paths: one flavoured with fish gelatin to signal a source of food; the other populated by another crayfish to potentially provoke an aggressive response.
  Continue reading
  The M in M1 is for moans: How do you turn a new MacBook Pro into a desktop workhorse?
     The M1 MacBook Pro is like that brilliant colleague who insists on microwaving fish in the office kitchenette. Good at its job, certainly, but also deeply annoying.
  On one hand, this machine is a veritable beast. It's fast, quiet, and has the best battery life of any machine this reviewer has used. Yet it suffers from two distinct flaws. First, it is reliant on just two USB-C (in this case, Thunderbolt 4) ports for external expandability. Secondly, for whatever reason, it natively supports just one external display.
  Fortunately, these are fairly straightforward to circumvent, provided you've got some deep pockets. A few weeks ago, Anker sent us  its PowerExpand 5-in-1 Thunderbolt 4 dock to review. Priced at £200, it's not cheap.
  Continue reading
  Sponsored With the progress of clouds, organizing IT infrastructure is no harder than organizing pizza delivery.
  According to MarketsandMarkets, by the end of 2021, cloud data centers will process over 94% of the total workload. It’s easy to explain why businesses migrate to clouds: companies like how simple it is to rent capacities and solutions from providers. However, all that is more relevant to virtual machines.
  The situation around dedicated servers is not as simple. They are, however, still indispensable for certain tasks, and allow client’s business to get the most out of its infrastructure. Our review of bare metal servers will show their advantages, when they are indispensable and how to seamlessly integrate them into corporate IT infrastructure.
  Continue reading
  Hubble telescope in another tight spot: Between astrophysicists sparring over a 'dark matter deficient' galaxy
  One team says DF2 is 72m LY away, another disagrees – we speak to both sides
     Never mind memory errors from radiation. Another deteriorating part of the decades-old Hubble Space Telescope has found itself in a jam. This time its camera unit is once again in the middle of a clash between scientists over whether or not the galaxy NGC 1052-DF2 contains any dark matter.
  When DF2 was  written up in a  Nature paper in 2018, the study immediately raised eyebrows. The paper concluded the galaxy was devoid of dark matter. How could that be possible?
  The mysterious substance is thought to be present in all galaxies, holding together glittering stars, swirls of dust and gas, and more, giving the galaxies structure and shape. Dark matter is a crucial component in theories of galactic formation, and finding a galaxy without this hidden stuff, or a very low quantity of it, breaks all the rules. DF2 was heralded as a significant oddball.
  Continue reading
  The Register - Independent news and views for the tech community. Part of Situation Publishing
title: 数据的多云太复杂了
title_en: Multi-cloud for data is too complicated

note: Apple成为2021年的第五大的PC品牌在印度，桌面的出货量，笔记本电脑，平板电脑的工作站合并到208,000个单位，根据Canaalys。 CanAlys指出，Apple的笔记本和印度片剂出货量中的高度促进是在2020年9月20日在网上商店开设的Apple。  研究公司IDC的数字也显示苹果公司的PC出货量Inindia（不包括平板电脑）在第一个Quart的年度增长335.5％，只有大约2,000个单位落后的Asustek。  印度的iPhone销售额最多，但这些数字是关于Mac和（我认为）iPad的。 在过去的20年里，苹果已经改变了很多，但有一件事保持不变：它们在有自己的商店，在线或身体上销售更多产品。
note_en:
Apple became the fifth largest PC brand in India in the firstquarter of 2021, with shipments of desktops, notebooks, tabletsand workstations combined to reach 208,000 units, according todata from Canalys. Canalys pointed out that the significantincrease in Apple’s notebook and tablet shipments in India was duemainly to Apple opening its online store in September 2020.
 Research firm IDC’s figures also show Apple’s PC shipments inIndia (excluding tablets) grew 335.5% on year in the first quarterand only lagged Asustek’s by around 2,000 units.
 iPhone sales in India are up to, but these numbers are about the Mac and (I think) iPads. A lot has changed for Apple in the last 20 years, but one thing remains unchanged: they sell more products when they have their own stores, online or physical.
title: Apple Mac销量去年苹果开业后在印度三倍
title_en: Apple Mac Sales Triple in India After Apple Opened Online Store Last Year

note:
Andy Weir的“Martian”及其电影适应所针对的Ridley Scott，仍然是我最喜欢的一些科幻作品。回到我写了技术评论的那一天。我上次阅读了2015年的这本书（直到2周前）并在2018年观看这部电影。
 最近，我一直详细探讨星舰如何改变游戏与月球探索如何，开始怀疑“火星”与基于星舰的架构看起来像什么，而不是书中使用的更昂贵且复杂的架构。
   这本书在其架构中并不完全自我统一，但重新签约，大约25个地图集的助推器推出用于组装6人到火星的零件和用品。每次旅行需要4年，并在表面上提供30天。每次任务在5多个任务中摊销了Hermes成本，每项任务均为30亿美元，或每人每天16600万美元。这是一个保守的估计 - 第12章刘易斯说：“山姆叔叔为每秒支付了十万美元”，整个方案的工作约为260亿美元，或65亿美元。在美国宇航局目前的预算的背景下，总共是非常雄心勃勃的！
 相比之下，基于星舰的特派团针对Martian表面进行了优化的高批量货物。随着货物费用约为1000美元/公斤，延长的船员任务甚至城市建筑成为最自然的活动，人员从O（1000美元）到O（1000美元/天）下降。这有很大的不同！
  与火星不同，只有一个新的空间车辆，而不是五或六个。边际单位成本可能是10亿美元，而不是5亿美元。它是迅速的可重复使用，并在100点到地面提供货物。不幸的是，对于“火星”，Starship Edition，方案脆性的丧失和压倒性的系统复杂性意味着剧情不能依赖于各种Mackuffins和基于科学的博览会之间的稳定性。或者至少，不用同样的方式。
 相反，它必须争辩在稀缺后景观中的孤独人类的熟悉历程。在某些方面，这可能能够更彻底地检查人类状况，但它也会提出绘图动机的挑战。
  为了完整性，这是2020年代的马斯地球和地球马斯“Porkchop”情节。广泛地说，推出仅在蓝色地区建议。 
六天进入我生命中最大的月份，它变成了噩梦。
 我在离开夜晚的庆祝活动中加载了。火星上550天，是时候回家了。乘坐流浪者旋转到基地周围旋转，以便最后一看火星地平线，在星舰上寄宿来，将带我们回家，爬进我的铺位，然后去睡觉。
 第二天早上我醒来并意识到我不在太空。好吧，我在太空中，从某种程度上，一切都在空间，但我仍然在一个停放在火星上的星舰。我们是否有理由推迟推出？不。
 不，我们没有。我看着窗外，在主要拖拉的另一边看到一个黑色的斑点，另一个被另一个欧姆特星舰推出，哦，前6个小时。它没有叫醒我。
 需要一段时间才能让1200吨燃料燃料燃料中的一个燃料，所以与此同时，我显然我显然是在一个星球上搁浅，只有5000吨的公司和300天等到下一个船员到来。
 但那不是有趣的部分。有趣的部分是货物清单数据库已被损坏。在我当前的职位不到2英里，有几十个星舰仍然装满了鳃的一切，带来了一个不断增长的火星基地可能需要。灯泡托盘。集装箱机器人。几十名机器人机器能够基本上给出了正确指令的任何动作。
 我可以搜索数据库并验证我有10,000天的食物供应 - 肯定足以看到我 - 但没有卸下每一个最后的星舰，我发现任何一个都会消失。只是想到所有那些孤独的三明治和羊角面包让我的肚子捏一点。 
在这里，我是一个令人难以置信的囤积物的小龙，我不知道任何东西。  当宇航员在中心蜷缩时，摇头摇晃着咆哮的风。 他们中的所有六个现在都穿着他们的航天套装，以防他们不得不争夺MAV的紧急起飞。 Johanssen看着她的笔记本电脑，而其余的看着她。  “现在持续一百千克，”她说。 “偶然到二十五岁。”  “耶稣，我们会在奥兹结束，”Watney说。 “中止风速是什么？”  “技术上是五十千克，”马丁内斯说。 “不仅仅是倾翻的危险。”  “对不起，指挥官，”马丁内斯承认了。 “沃特尼会好的。 这是火星。 低气压密度意味着150 kph风也不是可感知的。 什么都不会提示出星舰。“  “我想我看起来很愚蠢地穿着12个月之前的飞行套装我们推出推出？” 沃特尼问道。 
我最好在失败的通信系统上运行诊断。它肯定看起来最新的软件更新砖头。 NASA似乎不太可能将造成永久性的补丁，但随后再次谁真正了解Linux？
 现在我面临着困境。通过违禁品的各种垃圾箱捕捉，USB驱动器寻找早期的软件形式，因此我可以手动刷新ROM，或者在简单的范围内彻底地重新攻击数千个无线电。
 成千上万的无线电？嗯，是。蓝牙？收音机。无线上网？收音机。 GSM？收音机。 5G？收音机。 Zigbee？收音机。资产跟踪器？收音机。无线电无线电。但在这个勇敢的新世界中，我们所有的粪便互联网都有收音机内置。这是一个安全噩梦。但只有USB驱动器被禁止......
 当然，一个2 W蜂窝变送器几乎没有能够将Live Video流回地球，但Shannon-Hartley定理表明您仍然可以通过非常嘈杂的频道传输数据。我将在某种概要中放置一个牺牲物联网，加载WSPR错误纠正软件，并开始传输状态信标。信封数学的后面建议我可以每天发送和接收几千位，当我与潜艇代码书相结合时，我可以充分地保持灯光，直到我找到备用Quarllink接收器的托盘。
 我会使用ASCII字母表编写自己的编码系统吗？为什么我会膨胀一个26个字符的字母表已经非常冗长到256个字符？保留MMLAUT的90％的频道，以便NASA可以在没有任何歧义的情况下写出£¢〜√©％}}请！
 当然，它是琐碎的网络所有本地无线电，所以我不必向附近的流浪者做EVA来检查我的电子邮件。 1982年是什么？
  让我们有条不紊地思考这个。今天我很适合，随机挑选一个货物星舰，开车到它的基地，激活了外部升力，并轻轻地抬起到它的海绵体举行。除了它是如此完满，我几乎看不到，更不用说爬行，每个货舱都在不透明的白色压力套筒中包裹，以防止真空暴露。当然，每个货舱也用巨型QR码描述了描述内容的巨型码，因为我的眼睛不是像素化的，我无法解码。有用。 
我把托盘拿到了我的流浪者的托盘上，把它带回了蹄兵进入气闸，然后突破了密封，找到...轴承。我现在有10,000个各种尺寸的轴承。零营养含量。
 让我们做数学。我可以每天卸下4个托盘，在它过于移动之前，我的hab可能包含20。每个星舰都包含200托盘，所以......这种方法不缩放。我发现托盘的几率我可以在我死在老年期间看起来很苗条。
 是时候思考更大的时间。这些星舰的某个地方是建造大型加压帐篷的材料容易大，足以包含所有货物。最初，我们的意思是做一些探矿，下一个船员将部署基础材料，以便这里的船员永远不会受到限制。
  我破解了敞开的笔记本电脑，开始黑客攻击。首先，我没有理由在一个星舰身体上出现才能卸下它。显然，某些东西需要收集每个货物托盘，否则他们会堆积在基地上，但我在每个罗珀上丢弃了一些代码，使其能够与星舰货物起重机协调以同步位置并采购托盘。
 因为这是未来，所以在相机中覆盖，我可以轻松监督并在进入过程中调整过程。我的队伍队伍已经在播出了各种各样的星际舰艇的过程中，将他们的货物驾驶到选定的位置，并将其放在地上。
 这意味着，在我的准孤立状态下，我决定了第一个火星基地的实际建立在哪里。所以我正在挑选一个很好的观点。
 经过一周左右的持续运营，所有5000吨的货物现在都在整齐的行中，我可以在开放式漫游者来回驾驶。 
在我手中，当我驾驶是一种X射线荧光枪，旨在为勘探进行近表面矿物的非接触式测定，并且在这种情况下，无标记的货物包。在45分钟后开车上下行驶的一流辐照这已经被照射了冰冻的沙漠Hellscape，我终于得到了我一直在寻找的东西 - 一个强大的氟签名。
 氟通常是一种相当反社会的小原子，但在聚合物中取代氢气制成非常紫外线和耐化学物质。我剪了包装，发现......
 Teflon炊具。好的，我在正确的轨道上，但我今天不开店。回到驾驶。
 当我得到第二次击中时，太阳在西边。这次，我达到了污垢。增强PTFE帐篷材料。亩的东西。我把包裹叉到货物MIDDEN的中心，然后转入夜晚。
 在我去睡觉之前，我任务是一个搬家，以适应壕沟工具并挖掘新围栏的周边。
 第二天早上我开车回网站，发现我的路径被沟槽阻挡了。杜。我填写了一点，然后XRF枪在手中我发现墙壁锚托盘，将它们埋在沟槽中，然后将帐篷材料从中心拉出到拉链的边缘。
 我说它很容易。除了我是一个旨在在一年或两大年度复制整个工业革命的东西的唯一行星首领。所以它只是屁股的痛苦。有时努力移动操纵杆以驾驶巨大而强大的车辆导致我迷失了我的头盔。 
请参阅下一张发生的情况下的铆接说明步骤12-20：我的所有货物现在都在20英亩的充气围栏下。里面，温室效果开始热情令人沮丧，所以他们不再令人难以置信地冷 - 只是平定的。
 我的陪审团操纵通胀设立了足够的压力来保护货物，所以我继续打开每个最后的托盘。这我用手做了。用链条锯。我不是野蛮人，有一千个托盘打开。但是一个虎搬机器人电锯过于金属，即使对我而言。
 当所有人都说完成时，我基本上有世界上最悠久的最孤独，最糟糕的露天集市，大多数情况下，虽然不是完全识别的。我解开了生命支持物理厂房的寿命，让它成立，当内饰是衬衫袖子兼容时，用手重建我的货物清单。
 我作为一个小孩在超市工作。这就像股票一样，除了在转变结束之前弥补它并不是可行的策略。
 我花了十个星期让一切都没有包装，当我完成后，我回复了我的灯塔。美国国家航空航天局致死地将清单数据库解密密码发给我明文。它是“Cargo_manifest_123”。所以现在我知道现在一切都在现在的空星舰上。伟大的。
 我很惊喜，这么少的人可以做得很快。很快，他们就会在没有困扰的情况下建立新的火星城市。更好。
  Mindy Park继续仔细阅读其余的图像。哈夫完好无字，为什么不这样？外星人？ Kapoor博士无论如何都很乐意看到这一点。 
“Kapoor博士，不是紧急的，但我注意到，自从剩下的船员离开以来，基地的活动一直在继续，是机器人团队继续？ 如果是这样，为什么他们在备份城市网站位置似乎是货物托盘？ 而巨大的形状......“  “是的，”米奇说。 “我们要从ares 3船员中留下多长时间？ 他们都认为沃特尼的死了。 这是士气的巨大流失。“  “不，你讨论过它，”米奇被打断了。 “他们认为他们失去了船员。 他们被摧毁了。“  “当他们发现他们抛弃了拐杖？” Venkat问道。 “他们会感觉更好吗？”  mitch用手指戳了桌子。 “他们应该知道。 你认为指挥官刘易斯无法处理真相吗？“  “这是一个士气的问题，”Venkat说。 “他们可以专注于回家 - ”  “我打电话，”米奇说。 “我是那个决定船员最好的人。 我说我们带他们速度。“ 
Venkat看着米奇。 “我认为我们控制了所有流向和来自爱马仕的数据？”  “他们是精英技术专家，”Mitch回答说：“他们可以建立一个VPN。 他们的浏览器流量是加密的。 这并不难。 我8岁的孩子从欧洲汇集Netflix节目。“  刘易斯：有人*咳嗽@astrojohannsen咳嗽*说她在推出之前验证了标记在他的铺旁。 看起来我们留下了他。 哎呀。 对不起@nasa。  “Venkat，我们可能有问题。 我表现出额外的100公斤意大利面，以便再次补给。“  “经典错误。 我们都完成了它。 你会相信，亚马逊Prime从火星的退货政策并不多得多。“  “几乎不！ 这不是20世纪的原始消费火箭。 目前物流实际上在API下面。 美国宇航局从未抱怨额外的里程！“  “我记得那些日子。 我们钻了一切，以节省重量，甚至是意大利面！“ 
但是，不是宇航员，当我们试图去除冗余解剖系统以节省体重时，他们总是被尖叫。“  “早上100岁的意大利面是一个很大的错误，但至少你在按大红色按钮之前没有意外地误导你的船员。”  “好点，为什么不用下一个船员送她回来？ 我会用米奇跑。 他会喜欢它。“  “是的，我认为我们可以重新安通规定，规定船员员工只能重新进入地球的大气，只要所有的生活成员都是物理存在的。”  “是的。 我很欣赏牺牲，但你可以想象美国宇航局会在没有能力达到一年的轨道上没有能力开始营业的火星运动吗？ 包括奇怪的意大利面食？“  “我认为他们想参加，但他们必须牺牲他们的探索。”  “为什么？ 美国宇航局，俄罗斯，esa，jaxa，地狱，即使是澳大利亚空间机构也可以为他们推出它。 下一个星舰在他们的方向上飞行？“ 
“目前的政策是每个发射窗口每周星际的一个星舰，因此我们在明年有大约十几个机会。我们可以用铅笔吗？“
     我手上有一段时间。好吧，这是一个施工的方式。现在NASA的通信系统备份，他们不会停止推动每个人都可以让他们的手来做东西。你知道发现你的流浪者在半夜开车的烦人有多烦人，并坚持认为它不能在一些模糊的生产线上扭动13,000个螺栓？
 你能相信失败者的无线电证明是如何成为的？罗弗天线在手中，我把火星赶到了我的成长基地，让我的思绪徘徊。
 所以我在这里。过度溢出的燃料厂，一堆机器人机器人工厂，一个小装饰湖，尚未用鱼储存，几十个空的星舰在一天内留在骨头上被报废。
 每个腿都有8条折叠裙子，可以调整位置，以确保在接地上稳定的着陆。我发现相关的加速度计并不像它的那样闪电，并且设计并设计了狡猾的计划。
 站在星舰的航班甲板上，我激活着陆模式，把加速度计放在手上，打开一些甜蜜的节拍，并开始摆动围绕着小的传感器。
 星舰电脑认为地面正在做一些非常有趣的事情，然后移动腿来补偿。慢慢地，慢慢地，整个宇宙飞船开始在景观中洗牌。在节拍之前，我已经到了发射垫的一半。 
一旦我倾倒了燃料厂坦克进入星舰，爬上船上，然后按下大红色按钮。坐在9.5 km / s的调度delta-v，我要去哪儿？
 8分钟后，我是一个漂亮的极地低火星轨道。在此之后，它是在Kerbal空间计划中的锻炼。我提升了，改变了飞机，气球回到，轨道的Phobos，降落了几天，走来走去，飞到缺少，同样的交易，然后回到LMO。我仍然有足够的燃料，几乎燃起回到地球，但发射窗口不太正确。所以我抛弃了几百吨的道具并重新进入，落在发射台上。我从裙子箱上安全劫持的流动站，然后赶回镇上。
  很快就有，下一个窗口打开了，下一个货物从上面开始下雨。我开车去了附近的山丘，所以我可以在午餐时间之前每天早上批量观看他们的6或7批次。很快，尘土飞扬的旧骨院加入了几十多个星舰，这次是他们的表现完好无损。
note_en:
“The Martian” by Andy Weir, and its  film adaptation directed by Ridley Scott, remain some of my all time favorite science fiction works. Way back in the day  I wrote a technical commentary. I last read the book in 2015 (until 2 weeks ago) and watched the film in 2018.
 More recently I’ve been exploring in detail how  Starship changes the game with Lunar exploration and began to wonder what “The Martian” would look like with a Starship-based architecture, rather than the rather more expensive and complex architecture used in the book.
   The book is not entirely self-consistent in its architecture, but to recap, about 25 launches of an Atlas V-like booster are used to assemble the parts and supplies for a 6 person trip to Mars. Each trip takes 4 years and provides a 30 day stay on the surface. Amortizing the Hermes cost over 5 missions, each mission works out to be about $30b, or $166m per person per day on Mars. This is a conservative estimate – in Chapter 12 Lewis says “Uncle Sam paid a hundred thousand dollars for every second we’ll be here” which works out to be about $260b for the whole program, or $65b/year. Either total is quite ambitious in the context of NASA’s current budget!
 In contrast, a Starship-based mission is optimized for high volume cargo delivery to the Martian surface. With cargo costs around $1000/kg, extended crewed missions and even city building become the most natural activity, and personnel costs drop from O($1000/s) to O($1000/day). This makes a big difference!
  Unlike the Martian, there is only one new space vehicle, instead of five or six. The marginal unit cost is perhaps $10m, instead of $5b. It’s rapidly reusable, and delivers cargo in 100 T lots to the surface. Unfortunately for “The Martian”, Starship edition, the loss of programmatic brittleness and overwhelming system complexity means that the plot can’t rely on steadily ricocheting between various  MacGuffins and science-based exposition. Or at least, not in the same way.
 Instead, it has to contend with the somewhat less familiar trope of a lonely human in a post-scarcity landscape. In some ways, this may enable a more thorough examination of the human condition but it also presents challenges for plot motivation.
  For completeness, here’s the Mars-Earth and Earth-Mars  “porkchop” plot for the 2020s. Broadly speaking, launches are only advisable in the blue regions.
      Six days into what should be the greatest month of my life, and it’s turned into a nightmare.
 I got loaded up at the departure night celebration. 550 days on Mars, time to head home. Took the rover for a spin around the base to get one last look at the Martian horizon, homed in on the Starship that will take us home, crawled into my bunk, and went to sleep.
 Next morning I woke up and realize that I’m not in space. Well, I am in space, in the sense that everything is in space somewhere, but I’m still in a Starship that’s parked on Mars. Did we delay our launch for some reason? No.
 No we didn’t. I looked out the window and on the other side of the main drag saw a blackened spot where the other ERV Starship launched, oh, 6 hours before. It didn’t wake me.
 It takes a while to make the 1200 T of fuel needed to fuel up one of these bad boys and fly home, so in the meantime I’m apparently stranded here on a planet with nothing but 5000 T of cargo for company and a 300 day wait until the next crew arrives.
 But that’s not the funny part. The funny part is that the cargo manifest database has been corrupted. Within 2 miles of my current position there are a few dozen Starships still loaded to the gills with everything a growing Mars base could possibly need. Pallets of light bulbs. Container loads of robots. Several dozen robotic machines capable of basically any action given the right instructions.
 I can search the database and verify that I have something like 10,000 days of food supply – surely enough to see me out – but without unloading every last Starship my odds of finding any of it is vanishingly small. Just the thought of all those lonely sandwiches and croissants made my stomach pinch a little.
 Here I am, a tiny dragon on an unbelievable hoard, and I don’t know where anything is.
  The Hab shook in the roaring wind as the astronauts huddled in the center. All six of them now wore their flight space suits, in case they had to scramble for an emergency takeoff in the MAV. Johanssen watched her laptop while the rest watched her.
 “Sustained winds over one hundred kph now,” she said. “Gusting to one twenty-five.”
 “Jesus, we’re gonna end up in Oz,” Watney said. “What’s the abort wind speed?”
 “Technically one fifty kph,” Martinez said. “Any more than that and the Starship’s in danger of tipping.”
  “Sorry, commander,” Martinez conceded. “It’s going to be okay, Watney. This is Mars. The low atmospheric density means that 150 kph wind is barely perceptible. Nothing is going to tip the Starship.”
 “I guess I look pretty silly wearing a flight suit 12 months before we’re due to launch?” Watney asked.
    I’d better run diagnostics on the failed communications system. It sure looks like that latest software update bricked it. Seems unlikely that NASA would ship a patch that broke stuff permanently, but then again, who really understands Linux these days anyway?
 Now I’m faced with a dilemma. Hunt through various bins of contraband USB drives looking for an earlier form of the software so I can manually reflash the ROM, or hack literally any of the thousands of radios within easy reach.
 Thousands of radios? Well, yes. Bluetooth? Radio. Wifi? Radio. GSM? Radio. 5G? Radio. Zigbee? Radio. Asset trackers? Radio. Radio radio radio. But in this brave new world of ours, all our Internet of Shit devices come with radios built in. It’s a security nightmare. But only the USB drives are forbidden…
 Of course, a 2 W cellular transmitter is hardly capable of streaming live video all the way back to Earth, but the  Shannon-Hartley theorem shows you can still transmit data over a very noisy channel. I’ll put a sacrificial IoT radio in some kind of cantenna, load up the WSPR error correcting software, and start transmitting a status beacon. Back of the envelope math suggests I can send and receive a few thousand bits a day, which when combined with a submarine code book I have handy will be adequate to keep the lights on until I can locate that pallet of spare Starlink receivers.
 Would I write my own coding system using the ASCII alphabet? Why would I inflate a 26 character alphabet that’s already pretty redundant to 256 characters? To reserve 90% of my channel for umlauts so that NASA can write £¢~√°©%}} without any ambiguity? Please!
 And of course it’s trivially easy to network all the local radios, so I don’t have to do an EVA to a nearby rover to check my email. What is this, 1982?
  Let’s think about this methodically. Today I suited up, picked a cargo Starship at random, drove to its base, activated the external lift, and was gently lifted up into its cavernous cargo hold. Except that it was so full I could barely see in, let alone climb around, and every cargo pallet was wrapped in an opaque white pressure sleeve to prevent vacuum exposure. Naturally, every cargo pallet was also annotated with a giant QR code describing the contents, which I am unable to decode because my eyes are not pixelated. Useful.
 I unloaded a pallet onto the tray of my rover, drove it back to the Hab and into the airlock, then broke through the seal to find … bearings. I now have 10,000 bearings of various sizes. And zero nutritional content.
 Let’s do the math. I can unload 4 pallets a day, and my Hab can contain perhaps 20 before it is too full to move. Each Starship contains 200 pallets, so… this approach does not scale. My odds of finding a pallet I can metabolize before I die of old age are looking pretty slim.
 Time to think bigger. Somewhere in those Starships are the materials to build a large pressurized tent easily big enough to contain all the cargo. Originally, we were meant to do some prospecting and the next crew would deploy the base materials, so that the crew up here was never material constrained.
  I cracked open my laptop and started hacking. First, there’s no reason I have to physically be present at a Starship to unload it. Obviously something needs to collect each pallet of cargo or else they’ll pile up at the base, but I dropped some code on each rover enabling it to coordinate with the Starship cargo crane to synchronize position and procure a pallet.
 Because it’s the future, everything is covered in cameras and I can easily oversee and tweak the process as it goes along. My fleet of rovers is already in the process of ransacking every Starship in sight, driving their cargo to a selected location, and dropping it on the ground.
 Which means that, in my quasi-isolated state, I’m deciding where the first Mars base is actually going to be built. So I’m picking the spot with a good view.
 After a week or so of continuous operations, all 5000 T of cargo is now knolled in neat rows where I can drive back and forth on the open rover.
 In my hand as I drive is an X-Ray Fluorescence gun, designed to perform contactless assays of near-surface minerals for prospecting, and, in this case, unmarked cargo bales. After 45 minutes of driving up and down the rows mindlessly irradiating this already irradiated frozen desert hellscape, I finally got what I’d been looking for – a strong fluorine signature.
 Fluorine is ordinarily a rather antisocial little atom but substituting for hydrogen in polymers makes a very UV and chemical resistant substance. I cut through the packaging and found …
 Teflon cookware. Okay, I’m on the right track, but I’m not opening a shop today. Back to driving.
 The sun was setting in the west when I got my second hit. This time, I hit pay dirt. Reinforced PTFE tent material. Acres of the stuff. I forked the package to the center of the cargo midden and turned in for the night.
 Before I went to sleep I tasked a rover to fit the entrenching tool and excavate the perimeter of the new enclosure.
 Next morning I drove back to the site and found my path blocked by a trench. Duh. I filled in a bit, then XRF gun in hand I found the wall anchor pallets, buried them in the trench, then pulled the tent materials out from the center to the edges where it zipped together.
 I’m making it sound easy. It would be impossible, except I’m the sole planetary heir to a boatload of stuff intended to replicate the entire industrial revolution in a year or two. So it was merely a pain in the ass. At times the effort of moving a joystick to drive the enormous and powerful vehicles around caused me to mist up my helmet.
 See instruction manual steps 12-20 for a riveting account of what happened next: All my cargo was now under a 20 acre inflatable enclosure. Inside, the greenhouse effect began to warm things up a bit so they were no longer incredibly cold – merely ordinarily cold.
 My jury rigged inflation set up provided enough pressure to protect the cargo so I proceeded to open every last pallet. This I did by hand. With a chain saw. I’m not a barbarian, and there are like a thousand pallets to open. But a rover-mounted robot chainsaw is too metal, even for me.
 When all was said and done, I basically had the world’s loneliest and most poorly organized open-air bazaar full of stuff that was mostly, though not entirely, recognizable by sight. I unpacked the life support physical plant gear, got it set up, and when the interior was shirt sleeves compatible, rebuilt my cargo manifest by hand.
 I worked in a supermarket as a kid. This was like a stock take, except that making it up before the shift ended wasn’t a viable strategy anymore.
 I had spent ten weeks getting everything unpacked and when I was done, I got a reply to my beacon. NASA thoughtfully sent me the manifest database decryption passcode in plaintext. It was “cargo_manifest_123”. So now I know where everything was on the now empty Starships. Great.
 I was pleasantly surprised that so much could be done so quickly with so few people. Soon they’ll be building new Mars cities without bothering to send any astronauts at all. Even better.
  Mindy Park moved on to perusing the rest of the image. The Hab was intact of course, why wouldn’t it be? Aliens? Dr. Kapoor would be happy to see that anyway.
    “Dr Kapoor, not urgent but I noticed that activity at the base has been continuing since the crew left, are the robotics teams proceeding? If so, why are they siting what seem to be cargo pallets in the backup city site location? And in the shape of a giant …”
   “Yeah,” Mitch said. “How long are we gonna keep this from the Ares 3 crew? They all think Watney’s dead. It’s a huge drain on morale.”
   “No, you discussed it,” Mitch interrupted. “They think they lost a crewmate. They’re devastated.”
 “And when they find out they abandoned a crewmate?” Venkat asked. “Will they feel better then?”
 Mitch poked the table with his finger. “They deserve to know. You think Commander Lewis can’t handle the truth?”
 “It’s a matter of morale,” Venkat said. “They can concentrate on getting home—”
 “I make that call,” Mitch said. “I’m the one who decides what’s best for the crew. And I say we bring them up to speed.”
    Venkat looked at Mitch. “I thought we controlled all the data flowing to and from the  Hermes?”
 “They’re elite technical experts,” Mitch replied, “They can set up a VPN. Their browser traffic is encrypted. It’s not hard. My 8 year old does it to stream Netflix shows from Europe.”
     Lewis: Someone *cough @AstroJohannsen cough* said she verified Mark was in his bunk before we launched. Looks like we left him behind. Whoops. Sorry @NASA.
   “Venkat, we may have a problem. I manifested an additional 100 kg of pasta for the early resupply.”
     “Classic error. We’ve all done it. And would you believe, Amazon Prime’s return policy from Mars isn’t much good.”
  “Hardly! This isn’t the 1900s with their primitive expendable rockets. Logistics is practically below the API nowadays. And NASA never complains about getting the extra miles!”
 “I remember those days. We drilled holes in everything to save weight, even the spaghetti!”
 “Not the astronauts, though, they always squealed when we tried to remove redundant anatomical systems to save weight.”
 “Well 100 T of pasta is a big mistake, but at least you didn’t accidentally miscount your crew before pressing the big red button.”
   “Good point, why not send her back out with the next crew? I’ll run it by Mitch. He’ll love it.”
    “Yes, I think we can retcon a regulation stipulating that crew members may only re-enter Earth’s atmosphere provided all living members are physically present.”
   “Yes. I appreciate the sacrifice but can you imagine NASA would have ever begun a crewed Mars campaign without the ability to lift a million tonnes a year to orbit? Including oddly large orders of pasta?”
 “I think they want to participate, but they would have to sacrifice their probe.”
 “Why? NASA, Russia, ESA, JAXA, hell, even the Australian Space Agency could launch it for them. When is the next Starship flight in their direction?”
 “Current policy is no fewer than one Starship per planet per launch window, so we have half a dozen opportunities in the next year. Can we pencil them in?”
     I’ve had some time on my hands. Well, that’s one way of putting it. Now that NASA’s communications system is back up, they won’t stop driving every robot they can get their hands on to do stuff. Do you know how annoying it is to find your rover drove off in the middle of the night and insists it can’t return until it’s torqued 13,000 bolts on some obscure production line?
 Can you believe how failure prone that rover’s radio turned out to be? Rover antenna in hand, I drove my Mars car around my growing base and allowed my mind to wander.
 So here I am. An overproductive fuel plant, a bunch of robotic robot factories, a small decorative lake that is yet to be stocked with fish, and a few dozen empty Starships waiting in a bone yard to be scrapped for parts some day.
 Each has 8 little legs that fold out under the skirt and can adjust position to ensure stable landings on uneven ground. I found that the relevant accelerometer was not as well bolted down as it should be, and devised a cunning plan.
 Standing on the Starship’s flight deck, I activating landing mode, put the accelerometer in my hand, turned on some sweet beats, and started wiggling that little sensor around.
 The Starship computer thought the ground was doing something very funny and moved the legs to compensate. And slowly, slowly, the entire spaceship began to shuffle across the landscape. I was halfway to the launching pad before the beat even dropped.
 Once there I dumped the fuel plant tanks into the Starship, climbed aboard, and pressed the big red button. Sitting atop 9.5 km/s of dispatchable delta-V, where was I going to go?
 8 minutes later I was in a nice polar Low Mars Orbit. After this it was an exercise in Kerbal Space Program. I boosted out, changed planes, aerobraked back in, orbited Phobos, landed for a couple of days, walked around, flew to Deimos, same deal, then went back to LMO. I still had enough fuel practically to fly back to Earth but the launch window wasn’t quite right. So I dumped a few hundred tons of prop and re-entered, landing back on the launch pad. I unstowed my safely hijacked rover from the skirt cargo bin and drove back into town.
  Soon enough the next window opened up and the next lot of cargo began to rain down from above. I drove out to a nearby hill so I could watch them come in in batches of 6 or 7, every morning just before lunch time. Soon the dusty old bone yard was joined by a few dozen more Starships, this time with their manifests intact.
title: “火星”+星舰

note:
哦，看，疯狂的Microsoft Build出现了！今年的Microsoft Build是，你知道，再次全部虚拟。作为对.NET和WSL开发更感兴趣的人，我发现整个会议中提到了没有大量的Windows开发令人失望。它让我让我想念2019年。虽然我仍然没有从我的师父的学习中恢复过来，但我的笔记本电脑在建造会议期间死亡;我只能提供今年的构建的简单摘要。好吧，我认为让我们潜入。
   为了我的失望，这构建中没有太多新的。此构建通常缩写了我们到目前为止的所有内容，例如WSLG和“WSL  -  Install`。我注意到的唯一新的事情是使用WSLG使用WSL中的WSL中​​使用浏览器进行调试的能力。
   关于.NET的会话包装有信息，尽管有几个关于它的会话数。 .NET升级助手（帮助将.NET项目升级到最新版本）是我将我的旧项目迁移到更新版本，而且.NET 6与其单堆叠（只有一个SDK，BCL，Toolchain）平台）结构使它看起来非常有前途。以下是从会话中快速总结：
note_en:
Oh, look, a wild Microsoft Build appeared! The Microsoft Build this year was, you know, all virtual again. As a person who is more interested in .NET and WSL development, I find it disappointing that not much of Windows development is mentioned in the entire conference. It made me miss  Build 2019. While I am still not recovered from my master’s study, my laptop died right during the Build conference; I can only provide a straightforward summary of this year’s Build. Well, I think let’s dive in.
   To my disappointment, there is not much new in this build. This build generally recapped everything we have so far, such as WSLg and ``wsl --install`. The only new thing I noticed is Visual Studio’s ability to debug using the browser in WSL using WSLg.
   The sessions about .NET is packed with information, although there is nearly 1-digit number of sessions about it. .NET Upgrade Assistant (Help upgrade .NET project to latest version) would be possibly a great tool for me to migrate my old projects to newer version, and .NET 6 with its Single stack (only one SDK, BCL, Toolchain for cross-platform) structure made it looks really promising. Here is a quick sum up from the  session:
title: Microsoft Build 2021：我的小小的摘要
title_en: Microsoft Build 2021: My Tiny Little Summary
